factoid: Someone said 'In a year you will learn to know yourself...'.
Natásha repeated 'A whole year!'.
Natásha realized that the marriage was to be postponed for a year.
Natásha asked 'But why a year? Why a year?...'.
Prince Andrew began to explain to Natásha the reasons for the delay.
Natásha did not hear Prince Andrew.
Natásha asked 'And can't it be helped?'.
Prince Andrew did not reply to Natásha.
Prince Andrew's face expressed the impossibility of altering the decision.
Natásha cried 'It's awful! Oh, it's awful! awful!'.
Natásha burst into sobs.
Natásha said 'I shall die, waiting a year: it's impossible, it's awful!'.
Natásha looked into Prince Andrew's face.
Natásha saw in Prince Andrew's face a look of commiseration and perplexity.
Natásha said 'No, no! I'll do anything!'.
Natásha checked her tears.
Natásha said 'I am so happy.'
The father and mother came into the room.
The father and mother gave the betrothed couple their blessing.
From that day Prince Andrew began to frequent the Rostóvs' as Natásha's affianced lover.
No betrothal ceremony took place.
Natásha's engagement to Bolkónski was not announced.
Prince Andrew insisted that Natásha's engagement to Bolkónski not be announced.
Prince Andrew said that because he was responsible for the delay he ought to bear the whole burden of it.
Prince Andrew said that he had given his word and bound himself forever.
Prince Andrew said that he did not wish to bind Natásha.
Prince Andrew gave Natásha perfect freedom.
Prince Andrew said that if after six months Natásha felt she did not love him she would have full right to reject him.
Natásha and her parents did not wish to hear of this.
Prince Andrew was firm.
Prince Andrew came every day to the Rostóvs'.
Prince Andrew did not behave to Natásha as an affianced lover.
Prince Andrew did not use the familiar 'thou' with Natásha.
Prince Andrew said 'you' to Natásha.
Prince Andrew kissed only Natásha's hand.
After their engagement, intimate and natural relations sprang up between Prince Andrew and Natásha.
It seemed as if Prince Andrew and Natásha had not known each other until then.
Prince Andrew and Natásha liked to recall how they had regarded each other when they were nothing to one another.
Prince Andrew and Natásha felt themselves now quite different beings.
Prince Andrew and Natásha were artificial before, now natural and sincere.
At first the family felt some constraint in intercourse with Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew seemed a man from another world to the family.
Natásha trained the family to get used to Prince Andrew.
Natásha proudly assured the family that Prince Andrew only appeared to be different.
Natásha assured the family that Prince Andrew was really just like all of them.
Natásha assured the family that she was not afraid of Prince Andrew.
Natásha assured the family that no one else ought to be afraid of Prince Andrew.
After a few days the family grew accustomed to Prince Andrew.
The family pursued their usual way of life without restraint in Prince Andrew's presence.
Prince Andrew took his part in the family's usual way of life.
Prince Andrew could talk about rural economy with the count.
Prince Andrew could talk about fashions with the countess and Natásha.
Prince Andrew could talk about albums and fancywork with Sónya.
The household expressed wonder at how it had all happened.
The household expressed wonder at the evident omens.
Prince Andrew's coming to Otrádnoe was an omen.
Their coming to Petersburg was an omen.
The likeness between Natásha and Prince Andrew was noticed by her nurse on his first visit.
Andrew's encounter with Nicholas in 1805 was an omen.
Many other incidents betokened that it had to be.
In the house poetic dullness and quiet reigned.
Poetic dullness and quiet always accompanied the presence of a betrothed couple.
When all sitting together everyone kept silent.
Sometimes others would get up and go away and the couple, left alone, remained silent.
The couple rarely spoke of their future life.
Prince Andrew was afraid and ashamed to speak of his future life.
Natásha shared Prince Andrew's feelings.
Natásha constantly divined Prince Andrew's feelings.
Natásha began questioning Prince Andrew about his son.
Prince Andrew blushed when questioned about his son.
Prince Andrew said that his son would not live with them.
Natásha asked 'Why not?' in a frightened tone.
Prince Andrew said 'I cannot take him away from his grandfather, and besides...'.
Natásha said 'How I should have loved him!'.
Natásha guessed Prince Andrew's thought.
Natásha said 'but I know you wish to avoid any pretext for finding fault with us.'
